content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's just the right difficulty for a 5-15 minute clash, given a fairly good knowledge of a language like Python, Ruby, or Java, or even C++

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's great!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple, short and straight to the point. Multiple fun ways to solve and a few "traps", even though the logic seem so simple.

Why do you have to output whole numbers with decimal places. Why not just whole number if whole and with decimal if there is any? Would it not be better if instead the decimals had to be limited to 1 or 2 so you wont get long numbers like 2.3349609375. Cant it cause rounding errors if there are too many decimal places?
Why "separated by a slash (/)." and not "separated by a space" ?

Title
* Please change "high" to "heights".

Goal
* Please rewrite as:

A ball bounces until its bounce height is 2 centimeters or lower. Given the first bounce height [[h]] of the ball, and that each bounce height is half of the last one, output all the bounce heights from start to end.

Input
* Please rewrite as:

An integer [[h]] for the first bounce height in centimeters.

Output
* Please rewrite as:

All bounce heights from start (excluding [[h]]) to end, separated by a slash ({{/}}). 1 decimal place should be shown for integers, and all decimal places should be shown for non-integers.
If there is no bounce to output, print {{invalid bounce}}.

Constraints
* Please format "h" as a [[variable]].

Cases
* Please add a pair of cases where [[h]] is greater than 4 and at the same time a power of 2.

Thanks.
Because it adds a little difficulty, where rather than separating by a space, which is the default option and will be done by itself, here the programmer have to separate by himself.
